snippet: The attack by the Taliban at a restaurant in Kabul narrowed a gap between the Westerners who live an often cosseted existence, and ordinary Afghans, who have borne the brunt of the war’s violence.
abstract: Suicide bombing by Taliban in Kabul, Afghanistan, restaurant that killed 21 people, 13 of them foreigners, has helped to bridge divide between Westerners and ordinary Afghans; attack, deadliest against Western civilians since 2001, highlights growing antipathy toward Western mission felt by Pres Hamid Karzai.

byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
byline.contributor: Jawad Sukhanyar, Habib Zahori and Haris Kakar contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The attack by the Taliban at a restaurant in Kabul narrowed a gap between the Westerners who live an often cosseted existence, and ordinary Afghans, who have borne the brunt of the war’s violence.

headline.main: An Attack on Westerners Helps Bridge a Divide in Kabul
headline.print_headline: An Attack on Westerners Helps Bridge a Divide in Kabul

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
